The execution result of the Python code snippet is the list [32, 1024, 7776, 32768, 100000], which contains the even numbers from the original list each raised to the power of 5.
This code demonstrates how to use list comprehensions to calculate the 5th power of each element in a list of even numbers.
When executed, this script will output [32, 1024, 7776, 32768, 100000], showcasing a powerful and succinct method for transforming list data in Python using mathematical operations.
This is a Python code snippet that describes how to use list comprehensions to filter out even numbers from a given list using the % symbol.
The execution logic of the Python code is to iterate through the list of numbers and select the element whose remainder when divided by 2 is zero, that is, an even number.
The execution result of the Python code snippet is the list [2, 4], which contains the even numbers extracted from the original list of numbers using the % symbol.
This code uses conditional statements and the % symbol in a list comprehension to create a new list consisting only of even numbers from the original list.
When executed, this script will output an even list via the % symbol, demonstrating a compact and efficient way to perform filtered list creation in Python.
This is a Python code snippet that describes how to use list comprehensions to filter out even numbers from a given list using the / symbol.
The execution logic of the Python code is to iterate through the list of numbers and select the element whose quotient when divided by 2 is zero, that is, an even number.
The execution result of the Python code snippet is a list [2, 4] containing even numbers extracted from the original list of numbers using the / symbol.
This code uses a conditional statement and the / symbol in a list comprehension to create a new list consisting only of even numbers from the original list.
When executed, this script will output an even list via the / symbol, demonstrating a compact and efficient way to perform filtered list creation in Python.
This Python code snippet calculates the average of a list of numbers my_list.

The execution logic of the Python code is that it uses the sum() function to calculate the total sum of the elements in my_List and then divides that sum by the number of elements in the list, obtained by len(my_List).
The execution result of the Python code snippet is the number 3.0, which is the average of the numbers in the list [1, 2, 3, 4, 5].
The code demonstrates the use of sum() and len() functions together to calculate the arithmetic mean of a list of numbers my_list.
When executed, this script will output the value 3.0, which is the calculated average of the elements in my_List, illustrating a basic statistical operation in Python.
This Python code snippet is designed to determine the length of the list my_list.
The execution logic of the Python code is to use the len() function to find the number of items in the list my_list.
The execution result of the Python code snippet is the integer 5, which is the count of elements in the list [1, 2, 3, 4, 5].
The code uses the len() function to assess the size of the list my_list, which is a common operation when working with lists in Python.
When executed, this script will output the value 5, which is the length of my_List, demonstrating how to determine the number of elements in a list in Python.
This Python code snippet concatenates elements from a list into a single string with a space  as a separator.
The execution logic of the Python code is that it uses the join() method to combine elements from my_List with a space  between them.
The execution result of the Python code snippet is the string "Hello FGCE", which is the concatenation of the two strings in my_List with a space  separator.
The code demonstrates the use of the join() method to merge list elements into a single string with a space.
When executed, this script will output "Hello FGCE", showing how the join() method can be used with different characters as separators.
This Python code snippet concatenates elements from a list into a single string with a '-'  as a separator.
The execution logic of the Python code is that it uses the join() method to combine elements from my_List with a '-' between them.
The execution result of the Python code snippet is the string "Hello-FGCE", which is the concatenation of the two strings in my_List with a '-' separator.
The code demonstrates the use of the join() method to merge list elements into a single string with a specified separator '-'.
When executed, this script will output "Hello-FGCE", showing how the join() method can be used with different characters as separators.
